# Quick Start

This guide walks you through creating your first documentation site with Great Docs in just a few minutes.

## Initialize Your Documentation

Navigate to your Python project's root directory and run:

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
great-docs init
```

Great Docs will automatically:

1. **Detect your docs directory** – Looks for existing `docs/`, `site/`, or `documentation/` folders
2. **Find your package** – Auto-detects your package name from `pyproject.toml` or directory structure
3. **Discover your API** – Finds all public classes, functions, and methods
4. **Create configuration** – Generates `_quarto.yml` with API sections
5. **Create landing page** – Converts your `README.md` to `index.qmd`
6. **Install assets** – Copies CSS, JavaScript, and post-processing scripts

You'll see output like this:

```{.default filename="Terminal output"}
Installing great-docs...
Using directory: docs
Copied docs/scripts/post-render.py
Copied docs/great-docs.css
Copied docs/github-widget.js
Detected package: my_package
Discovered 15 public names
  MyClass: class with 8 methods
  helper_function: function
  ...
Created docs/_quarto.yml
Created docs/index.qmd

Great Docs installation complete!
```

## Build Your Documentation

Once initialized, build your documentation with:

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
great-docs build
```

This single command:

1. Syncs your landing page with `README.md`
2. Refreshes the API configuration (discovers new exports)
3. Generates `llms.txt` for AI documentation indexing
4. Creates source links JSON for GitHub integration
5. Runs `quartodoc build` to generate API reference pages
6. Runs `quarto render` to build the HTML site

The built site is in `docs/_site/`.

## Preview Locally

To preview your documentation with live reload:

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
great-docs preview
```

This starts a local server and opens your browser. Changes to your documentation files trigger automatic rebuilds.

## Project Structure

After initialization, your project will have:

```{.default filename="Project structure"}
your-project/
├── docs/
│   ├── _quarto.yml          # Quarto configuration
│   ├── index.qmd            # Landing page (from README.md)
│   ├── great-docs.css       # Styling
│   ├── github-widget.js     # GitHub stars widget
│   ├── sidebar-filter.js    # API search filter
│   ├── llms.txt             # LLM-friendly docs index
│   ├── _source_links.json   # Source code links
│   ├── reference/           # API reference pages (generated)
│   │   ├── index.qmd
│   │   ├── MyClass.qmd
│   │   └── ...
│   └── scripts/
│       └── post-render.py   # HTML post-processing
├── pyproject.toml
├── README.md
└── your_package/
    └── ...
```

## Command Options

### Specifying Directories

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
# Initialize in a specific docs directory
great-docs init --docs-dir site

# Initialize a different project
great-docs init --project-path /path/to/project

# Combine both
great-docs init --project-path /path/to/project --docs-dir docs
```

### Force Overwrite

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
# Overwrite existing files without prompting
great-docs init --force
```

### Build Options

```{.bash filename="Terminal"}
# Build without refreshing API config (faster when API unchanged)
great-docs build --no-refresh

# Build with file watching (auto-rebuild on changes)
great-docs build --watch
```

## Using the Python API

You can also use Great Docs programmatically:

```{.python filename="Python"}
from great_docs import GreatDocs

# Initialize for current directory
docs = GreatDocs()
docs.install()

# Build documentation
docs.build()

# Or with specific paths
docs = GreatDocs(project_path="/path/to/project", docs_dir="docs")
docs.install()
docs.build()
```
